thread.title: Uganda: Police Buy 4,000 Bikes to Monitor Elections

title: Uganda: Police Buy 4,000 Bikes to Monitor Elections
text:
By Andrew Bagala 
Kampala — The police have procured 4,000 motorcycles to carry out patrols during the 2016 general election. 
Police are moving away from the use of routine foot patrols and vehicles to motorcycles as the main patrolling systems. Police declined to reveal how much they spent on the motorcycles. 
North Korean military instructors are training police officers under the Field Force Unit, a police paramilitary, on how to manoeuvre the motorcycles as they carry out their patrols. The Inspector General of Police, Gen Kale Kayihura, said by December this year, all the 4,000 motorcycles will be fully operational. 
"These officers on the motorcycles will be linked to police booths. I want visibility of officers on the ground to deter criminals," Gen Kayihura said. 
Police are planning to establish a division (around 10,000 officers) to undertake the new policing patrol system. 
The system is being experimented in Kampala Metropolitan Police with one regiment (800 officers) on the ground. 
It is expected to be moved up-country by December. It's aimed at increasing mobility and visibility, which has been the biggest police problem due to limited manpower. 
The main patrol vehicle has been a Toyota Land Cruiser 70 Series, which goes for Shs150m and carries not more than six officers. 
At the same amount, the police would have 40 motorcycles that would carry eighty officers, and penetrate deeper into the suburbs. 
Kampala Metropolitan Police spokesman, Mr Patrick Onyango, said a few squads have been deployed in some areas of the city centre. Uganda
